key_insight: DREX dynamically regroup batches at inference time so tokens/requests that are ready to exit can leave early without stalling others, improving GPU utilization and lowering latency while preserving output quality.
problem_solved: Traditional static batching is incompatible with Early-Exit LLMs because requests exit at different layers; existing fixes either waste compute by forcing late exits or hurt quality by forcing premature exits.
method: Monitor per-token/request exit readiness (e.g., confidence scores) during layer-by-layer inference and mark candidates for exit.
Dynamically split and reassemble micro-batches on-the-fly so ready items exit immediately while others continue through deeper layers, maximizing hardware utilization.
Lightweight scheduler that balances throughput vs. latency targets and enforces quality thresholds to avoid premature exits.
impact: Enables practical deployment of Early-Exit LLMs by reducing average latency and increasing throughput without degrading accuracy, yielding cost and energy savings for real-time and large-scale inference.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing tokens entering a layered model and individual tokens exiting at different depths with arrows that regroup into new micro-batches (Dynamic Rebatching loop).
Before vs After bar/line chart comparing latency, throughput, and compute (FLOPs) for standard batching, naive EE batching, and DREX.
Flowchart of the DREX scheduler: detect ready-to-exit → split batch → dispatch exits → continue deeper for remaining items.
Icon set: stacked model layers, stopwatch (latency), GPU utilization meter, shield/checkmark (quality preserved).
paper_title: Dynamic Rebatching for Efficient Early-Exit Inference with DREX
paper_authors: Xuting Liu, Daniel Alexander, Siva Kesava Reddy Kakarla, Behnaz Arzani, Vincent Liu
